definition[0]: to say that something will happen, before it happens
example[0]: Sales were five percent lower than predicted.
example[1]: As Liz had predicted, the rumours were soon forgotten.
example[2]: Newspapers predicted that Davis would be re-elected.
example[3]: It is difficult to predict what the long-term effects of the accident will be.
example[4]: Unemployment is predicted to increase to 700,000 by the end of the year.
explanation[0]: You predict that something will happen
example[5]: Experts predict that the economic situation will improve
explanation[1]: You predicted that something would happen
example[6]: Experts predicted that the economic situation would improve
explanation[2]: You predict that something might or could happen
example[7]: No one could have predicted that she might do something like that
explanation[3]: You say that something is predicted to happen
example[8]: The population is predicted to increase
explanation[4]: You say it is predicted that something will happen
example[9]: It is predicted that the population will increase
explanation[5]: You say that someone is predicting something Predict is often used in the progressive
example[10]: They are predicting another hot summer
example[11]: In the future, it may be possible to predict earthquakes.
example[12]: Scientists are trying to predict what the Amazon will look like in 20 years' time.
definition[1]: to say what is likely to happen in the future, especially in relation to the weather or the economic or political situation
example[14]: Economists forecast that there would be a recession.
definition[2]: to say what the amount, size, cost etc of something is likely to be in the future, using the information you have now
example[15]: The world’s population is projected to rise by 45%.
definition[3]: be able to know what will happen in the future
example[16]: No one can say what the next fifty years will bring.
example[17]: I can’t say exactly how much it will cost.
definition[4]: to say correctly what will happen in the future, using special religious or magical powers
example[18]: The woman claimed that she had the gift of foretelling the future.
example[19]: It all happened as the prophet had foretold.
definition[5]: to say that something will happen because you feel that it will, or by using special religious or magical powers
example[20]: He’s one of those people who are always prophesying disaster.
example[21]: The coming of a great Messiah is prophesied in the Bible.
example[22]: He prophesied that the world would end in 2012.
example[23]: Marx prophesied that capitalism would destroy itself.
definition[6]: to know that something is going to happen before it happens
example[24]: They should have foreseen these problems.
example[25]: No one foresaw the outcome of the war.
definition[7]: to have a strange feeling that something is about to happen, especially something bad, usually just before it happens
example[26]: Suddenly I had a strange premonition of danger ahead.
definition[8]: to say what you think will happen
example[27]: Wall Street had been predicting a quarterly profit of 5 cents per share.
example[28]: Economists are predicting that growth will slow.
